question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If a stack of eight quarters is exactly half an inch, how many quarters will be needed to make a stack one foot high?
inference:
Since 8 quarters = 1/2 inch, 16 quarters = 1 inch, so 192 quarters = 1 foot.
Final Answer: \boxed{$192$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: There are $12$ inches in a foot, so we can convert the units by multiplying ratios. $$\frac{8 \text{ quarters}}{\frac{1}{2}\text{ inch}}\times\frac{12 \text{ inches}}{1 \text{ foot}}=\frac{96}{\frac12}=192 \text{ quarters per foot}$$ A stack one foot high consists of $\boxed{192}$ quarters.
